questions.text: An example of a synchondrosis is a/an:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An epiphyseal plate is an example of a synchondrosis, which is a temporary cartilaginous joint present in growing bones.

Explanation of Other Options:

Options A & D: Articular disk and meniscus are fibrocartilaginous structures within synovial joints, not synchondroses.

Option C: The intervertebral disk is a fibrocartilaginous joint (secondary cartilaginous joint or symphysis).

questions.text: Which of the following structures is unique to a synovial joint?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The joint cavity is the hallmark of synovial joints, a space filled with synovial fluid that separates the articulating bones, enabling free and smooth movement.
  • Articular surfaces are covered by hyaline cartilage, which is avascular and lubricated by synovial fluid secreted by the synovial membrane lining the cavity.
  • The articular capsule, composed of a fibrous outer layer and an inner synovial membrane, encloses the joint cavity and maintains joint integrity.
  • Accessory ligaments, collateral ligaments, and bursae are commonly associated with synovial joints but are not unique, as some may be found in other joint types or connective tissue structures. (Options A, B & C ruled out)

questions.text: In an auto accident, the patient's knee strikes the dashboard which in turn pushes the head of the femur posteriorly out of its socket. Which ligament is most likely ruptured by this posterior dislocation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Three ligaments comprise the hip joint capsule: pubofemoral, iliofemoral, and ichiofemoral. The iliofemoral ligament forms the anterior wall of the hip capsule, the pubofemoral lies beneath the joint, and the ischiofemoral ligament forms the posterior free margin of the hip capsule. Since the ischiofemoral ligament is the posterior edge of the hip capsule, it is the ligament that is most likely to be injured if the femur is dislocated posteriorly. The transverse acetabular ligament is a structure that bridges the acetabular notch and forms a bridge over the artery in the ligament of the femoral head.

The fibrous capsule around the hip joint does not attach to the posterior aspect of the femur. This means the femur can dislocate backwards. The hip joint is also less stable and more prone to dislocating when it is flexed (like when a person is sitting). So, posterior femoral dislocations are classically seen in car accidents, when a seated passenger bangs his or her knees into the dashboard and femur is pushed posteriorly.

choices.text: Saddle joint, Ball and socket joint
Hinge joint, Ball and socket joint

questions.text: What type of synovial joints are represented by structures 1 and 2 in the image below, respectively?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The incudomalleolar joint is a saddle joint, and the incudostapedial joint is a ball-and-socket joint.

questions.text: The type of joint marked in the image below is
questions.solution:
Explanation:
The joint marked in the above image is the costotransverse joint, which is a synovial type of joint. It permits slight gliding movements between the tubercle of the rib and the transverse process of the vertebra, typical of plane synovial joints.

Synovial joints have a joint cavity, synovial membrane, and articular cartilage-allowing free movement.

Explanation of Other Options:

A synarthrosis (Option A) is an immovable joint (e.g., sutures of the skull). The costotransverse joint permits gliding movement, hence not synarthrosis.

A syndesmosis (Option B) is a fibrous joint where bones are connected by a ligament (e.g., inferior tibiofibular joint). Costotransverse joint is not fibrous, but synovial, so incorrect.

Synchondrosis (Option D) is a primary cartilaginous joint where bones are united by hyaline cartilage (e.g., epiphyseal plate, costochondral joint). Costotransverse joint has a synovial cavity, not cartilage between bones, so this is also incorrect.

questions.text: Forward and backward movements of the mandible at the temporomandibular joint are called, respectively:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Protraction is the forward movement of the mandible.
  • Retraction is the backward movement of the mandible.
  • These movements occur at the temporomandibular joint, allowing the lower jaw to move anteriorly and posteriorly.

questions.text: What type of joint is involved in the deformity shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows hallux valgus, a deformity involving excessive lateral deviation of the first metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joint.
The MTP joint is an example of an ellipsoid (condyloid) joint, characterized by:

  • An oval convex surface (male) fitting into an elliptical concave surface (female)
  • Biaxial movements: flexion-extension and abduction-adduction

Examples of ellipsoid joints:

  • Wrist joint (radiocarpal joint)
  • Metacarpophalangeal joints
  • Metatarsophalangeal joints
  • Atlanto-occipital joint

Explanation of Other Options:

Saddle joint (Option A):

  • Saddle joints have reciprocally concavo-convex articular surfaces. They allow biaxial movement with some conjunct rotation.
  • Examples: First carpometacarpal joint (thumb), sternoclavicular joint, calcaneocuboid joint.

Pivot joint (Option C):

  • Pivot joints allow uniaxial rotation around a vertical axis.
  • Examples: Superior/inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint..

Hinge joint (Option D):

  • Hinge joints permit uniaxial movement: flexion and extension only.
  • Examples: Elbow, ankle, interphalangeal joints.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy complains of pain near the shoulder after repeated strenuous activity involving lifting weights. Imaging shows a delayed ossification centre at the site of tendon attachment near the proximal humerus. This epiphysis is classified as which of the following types?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Traction epiphyses are non-articular ossification centres located at tendon attachment sites and ossify later than pressure epiphyses.
  • The clinical scenario describes delayed ossification at a tendon attachment site, consistent with a traction epiphysis.
  • Pressure epiphyses are involved in weight transmission and are articular in nature. (Option A ruled out)
  • Atavistic and aberrant epiphyses are rare and not typically located at tendon attachments. (Options C & D ruled out)

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text: Assertion (A): The lateral meniscus is more frequently injured than the medial meniscus. Reason (R): The medial collateral ligament is attached to the medial meniscus, making it less mobile.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The medial collateral ligament (tibial collateral ligament) is attached to the medial meniscus of the knee. This attachment limits the mobility of the medial meniscus, making it more susceptible to injury when the MCL is damaged, often due to a blow to the lateral side of the knee. (Assertion is false and Reason is true)
  • In contrast, the lateral collateral ligament (fibular collateral ligament) is not attached to the lateral meniscus. It is separated from the joint capsule by the tendon of popliteus, allowing the lateral meniscus greater mobility and reducing its risk of injury.
  • The anterior and posterior cruciate ligaments are intracapsular ligaments that connect the tibia to the femur, but they are not attached to either meniscus.

questions.text: A soldier developed "fallen arches" from marching with a heavy pack in boots that lacked arch support. The ligament that normally supports the head of the talus and is primarily responsible for holding up the medial longitudinal arch of the foot is the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament) connects the sustentaculum tali with the plantar surface of the navicular bone. It provides major support for the medial longitudinal arch of the foot, so this must be the ligament that the soldier injured. The calcaneometatarsal ligament is a superficial ligament in the foot, it the lateral band of the plantar aponeurosis. The long plantar ligament connects calcaneus with cuboid and the bases of lateral 3 metatarsals. The long plantar ligament is generally important in maintaining all the arches of the foot, but the spring ligament is specifically associated with the medial longitudinal arch and the head of the talus. The deltoid ligament is on the medial side of the ankle, this ligament stabilizes the ankle joint during eversion and prevents the ankle from dislocating. The short plantar ligament is deep to the long plantar ligament, it extends from the anterior aspect of the inferior surface of the calcaneus to the inferior surface of the cuboid.

questions.text: While water skiing in Florida following final exams, a medical student falls and twists her ankle. Her foot is forcibly everted, which could cause a sprain of which ligament?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The deltoid ligament connects medial malleolus with talus, navicular & calcaneus. It is on the medial side of the ankle joint, and its role is to prevent the ankle from dislocating when forcibly everted. So, if a foot was strongly everted, the deltoid ligament might tear.

The anterior talofibular ligament connects the lateral malleolus with the talus anterolaterally, and the calcaneofibular ligament connects the lateral malleolus with calcaneus. Both of these ligaments contribute to the lateral ligaments of the ankle, and they can be damaged during forced inversion of the foot.

The anterior tibiofibular ligament connects the tibia and the fibula, providing support to the distal ends of these bones. The plantar calcaneonavicular ligament (spring ligament) connects the sustentaculum tali with the plantar surface of the navicular bone. It provides major support for the medial longitudinal arch of the foot.

questions.text: What is the type of cartilage in the structure marked in the following image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure marked is the annulus fibrosus, which is composed of fibrocartilage. Fibrocartilage contains a mixture of white fibrous tissue and cartilaginous tissue, making it extremely tough and resilient.

Common Components of Cartilage:

  • Chondrocytes: These are the cartilage cells, reside within cave-like spaces called lacunae.
  • Chondrocytes originate from chondroblasts (stem cells found in the perichondrium).
  • Perichondrium: an outer layer present in most cartilage types, dense but irregular connective tissue.
    • Has an outer fibrous layer composed mostly of collagen fibers
    • Inner cellular layer contains chondroblasts.

Explanation of Other Options:

Calcified cartilage (Option C): Refers to hyaline cartilage that has undergone calcification, making it rigid; it is typically found in the growth plate during endochondral ossification but is not a distinct cartilage type like fibrocartilage.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have yellow cartilage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The septal nasal cartilage is composed of hyaline cartilage, not yellow cartilage.

Elastic cartilage (aka yellow cartilage) is rich in elastic fibers and provides both strength and flexibility. It is typically found in structures that require shape retention and pliability.

Examples of structures with elastic cartilage include:

  1. Apices of the arytenoid (Option C ruled out)
  2. Epiglottis (Option A ruled out)
  3. Corniculate cartilages
  4. Cuneiform cartilages
  5. Eustachian tube
  6. Pinna (Auricle) (Option B ruled out)
  7. External auditory

questions.text: Which of the following is not a sesamoid bone?
questions.solution:
Os trigonum is an accessory bone, not a sesamoid, located posterior to the talus. It is formed from an unfused secondary ossification centre, and often mistaken for a fracture on imaging.

Sesamoid bones are small bony nodules embedded within tendons or joint capsules.

  • They lack periosteum and ossify after birth.
  • Commonly found in areas of friction, pressure, or repetitive stress.
  • Covered with hyaline cartilage and lubricated by synovial fluid or a bursa.
  • Functions:
    • Resist pressure
    • Minimize friction
    • Alter direction of muscle pull
    • Preserve local vascular integrity

Examples of Sesamoid bone:

  • Patella: Largest sesamoid bone; in the quadriceps tendon
  • Pisiform: Tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris
  • Fabella: Tendon of the lateral head of gastrocnemius (Option A ruled out)
  • Hallux sesamoids: Tendon of flexor hallucis brevis (Option D ruled out)
  • Os peroneum: Within peroneus longus tendon (Option C ruled out)

choices.text: Cancellous bone is absent in the epiphysis
Cancellous bone is present in the outer cortex
Haversian system is absent in cancellous bone
Compact bone has lamellae arranged in a meshwork

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding long bones?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Haversian system is seen in compact bones, not cancellous bones.

Bone Types (Macroscopic Classification):

  • Compact bone: Dense, forms the outer layer of bones (especially diaphysis and cortex). (Option B ruled out)
  • Cancellous (spongy) bone: Porous, found in epiphysis and medullary regions. (Option A ruled out)

Haversian System (Osteon):

  • Found only in compact bone, not in cancellous bone.
  • Structural and functional unit of compact bone.
  • The outer surface of a bone is covered by the periosteum, and the inner surface lining the medullary cavity is called the endosteum.
  • Each osteon consists of the following components:
    • Central (Haversian) canal: Runs longitudinally through the bone and contains a neurovascular bundle (arteries, veins, and nerves), along with endosteum.
    • Concentric lamellae: Layers of calcified matrix with type I collagen arranged around the central canal. (Option D ruled out)
    • Lacunae: Small spaces located between lamellae, housing osteocytes (mature bone cells).
    • Canaliculi: Tiny channels connecting lacunae to each other and the central canal for exchange of nutrients, oxygen, and waste products.
    • Volkmann's (perforating) canals: Transverse channels that connect adjacent Haversian canals, allowing passage of neurovascular bundles between osteons and providing communication between central canals.

questions.text: The given joint is functionally classified as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a sagittal section of the knee joint, a classic example of a synovial joint. Synovial joints are freely movable and are therefore functionally classified as diarthroses.

Functional Classification of Joints (by Mobility)

  1. Synarthrosis (Immovable)
    • Bones joined by fibrous tissue
    • Example: Fibrous joints like skull sutures (Option B ruled out)
  2. Amphiarthrosis (Slightly Movable)
    • Bones connected by cartilage and ligaments
    • Acts as shock absorbers
    • Example: Cartilaginous joints like intervertebral discs (Option C ruled out)
  3. Diarthrosis / Synovial Joints (Freely Movable)
    • Freely movable joints with a fluid-filled synovial cavity between articular surfaces.
    • Articular surfaces are covered with articular cartilage; the joint is lined by a synovial membrane that secretes lubricating synovial fluid.
    • Movement is guided by joint shape, and restricted by ligaments and joint capsule.
    • Movements at Synovial Joints: Flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, rotation, circumduction, and gliding.
    • Example: Knee joint

Explanation of Other Options:

Syndesmosis (Option D): A type of fibrous joint (e.g., distal tibiofibular joint), not freely movable like synovial joints.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a pneumatic bone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The maxilla is a pneumatic bone.

Pneumatic bones contain air-filled cavities, which make them light-weight. They also aid in the resonance of sound and act as air conditioning chambers for inspired air. e.g., maxilla, sphenoid, ethmoid, etc.

choices.text: Progenitor cells are present in the outer fibrous layer
It is continuous with the capsule of the joint
It is devoid of nerve supply

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the layer of bone involved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given X-ray shows Codman's triangle, a triangular area of new subperiosteal bone formed when the periosteum is lifted by an aggressive lesion, such as an osteosarcoma. It represents an incomplete periosteal reaction, often associated with malignant bone tumors.

Periosteum:

The periosteum is a thick fibrous membrane that covers the outer surface of bones, except:

  • At articular surfaces (joints)
  • At entheses (insertion sites of tendons and ligaments)

At the articular margins, the periosteum is continuous with the joint capsule.

Layers of the Periosteum: (Option A ruled out)

  1. Outer Fibrous Layer
    • Composed of dense connective tissue
    • Contains fibroblasts
  2. Inner Cambium (Osteogenic) Layer
    • Rich in progenitor cells that can differentiate into osteoblasts (Option B ruled out)
    • Active in bone growth and repair

Vascular and Neural Supply

  • Blood Supply: Periosteum is nourished by periosteal arteries
  • Nerve Supply: It is highly innervated, making it the most pain-sensitive part of the bone (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: It is made of elastic cartilage
It is supplied only by epiphyseal arteries
It is the site for enchondral ossification

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding this structure?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure marked in the radiograph is the epiphyseal plate (growth plate), a zone of hyaline cartilage located between the epiphysis and metaphysis of long bones. It is the site of endochondral ossification, which is primarily responsible for the longitudinal growth of bones.

The epiphyseal plate receives dual blood supply from:

  • Epiphyseal arteries
  • Metaphyseal arteries

Fractures involving the epiphyseal plate are referred to as Salter-Harris fractures, and they can affect bone growth depending on the severity and classification.

questions.text: Which of the following bones violates the rule: "The secondary ossification centre that appears first, fuses last"?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The fibula violates the law of ossification, where the lower end ossification center appears first, but also fuses first, before the upper end.

Ossification is the process of bone formation that occurs at specific sites known as centres of ossification. These are points where osteoblasts, located around newly formed capillary loops, begin laying down lamellae (bone matrix).

Fusion and Growth:

  • Fusion of epiphyses with diaphysis begins at puberty and completes by around 25 years of age.
  • After this fusion, no further longitudinal growth of the bone is possible.
  • The growing end of a long bone is the epiphyseal end that fuses last, allowing maximum growth.

Law of Ossification:

"The secondary ossification center that appears first is usually the last to fuse."

  • This law holds true for most bones, including radius, ulna, sternum, humerus (upper end), femur (lower end), tibia (upper end) (Options A, C & D ruled out)
  • Exception: Fibula → The lower end ossification center appears first, but also fuses before the upper end.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is false, but R is true
A is true, but R is false

questions.text:
Assertion (A): The metaphysis is the most common site of osteomyelitis in adults.
Reason (R): Bacteria get trapped in the hairpin loops of end arteries in the metaphysis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The reason (R) is true:
    • The metaphysis has a rich supply of end arteries that form hairpin loops, particularly in children before epiphyseal fusion.
    • These sluggish, looping vessels are prone to bacterial trapping, making the metaphysis a common site for hematogenous spread of infection.
  • The assertion (A) is false:
    • In adults, the epiphyseal plate has fused, and metaphyseal vessels do not end blindly; instead, they anastomose with epiphyseal vessels.
    • Thus, osteomyelitis in adults more commonly involves the epiphysis or subchondral bone, not the metaphysis.
  • In children, however, the metaphysis is the most common site of osteomyelitis due to:
    • Persistent epiphyseal plate (which acts as a barrier)
    • Rich metaphyseal blood supply with hairpin bends

questions.text: Which ligament limits extension at the hip joint?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The iliofemoral ligament is a Y-shaped ligament extending from the anterior inferior iliac spine to the anterior surface of the intertrochanteric line of the femur. It prevents hyperextension of the hip joint during standing by screwing the femoral head into the acetabulum. (The ischiofemoral ligament also helps to prevent hyperextension of the hip joint by screwing the femoral head into the acetabulum). Ligamentum capitis femoris attaches the head of the femur to the acetabular fossa. The pubofemoral ligament connects the pubic portion of the rim of the bony acetabulum to the medial surface of the femoral neck. It prevents overabduction of the hip joint. Zona orbicularis is a band of circularly oriented ligamentous fibers that reinforce the capsule of the hip joint, it helps keep the head of the femur in its socket.

questions.text: Which of the following bones develops through intramembranous ossification?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Frontal bones undergo intramembranous ossification. Other bones listed have endochondral ossification.

Based on their development, bones can be classified into 3 categories:

  1. Membranous bones (dermal bones) are formed through intramembranous ossification. There is direct bone formation within highly vascular sheets or 'membranes' derived from mesenchymal condensations. e.g., bones of the vault of skull and facial bones (like frontal, lacrimal, nasal, zygomatic).
  2. Cartilaginous bones are formed by intracartilaginous (endochondral) ossification. Bone forms by ossification of a preformed hyaline cartilage model. This is the main method of bone formation in the body. e.g., bones of limbs, vertebral column, and thoracic cage. (Options A, B & D ruled out)
  3. Membranocartilaginous bones ossify from both cartilage and mesenchymal condensation. e.g., clavicle, mandible, occipital bone, temporal bone, and sphenoid bone.

questions.text: The joint shown in the image is also known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows Gomphosis (aka peg and socket joint), a type of fibrous joint.

Fibrous joints are immovable or allow minimal movement, joined by fibrous tissue. These are classified into:

  1. Sutures: Found in the skull
  2. Syndesmosis: Bones connected by interosseous ligament (e.g., inferior tibiofibular joint) (Option B ruled out)
  3. Gomphosis: Also called peg and socket joint (e.g., root of a tooth fits into its alveolar socket)

Explanation of Other Options:

Hinge joint (Option C): A type of synovial joint with pulley-shaped articular surfaces that allow movement in one plane (flexion and extension). E.g., elbow joint, ankle joint, interphalangeal joints.

Pivot joint (Option D): A type of synovial joint where a central bony peg rotates within a ring formed by bone and ligament. E.g.,: superior and inferior radioulnar joints, median atlantoaxial joint

questions.text: Which of the following structures do the Sharpey's fibers connect ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sharpey's fibers are thick collagen fibers that serve as anchoring structures.

  • In Bones:
    • Sharpey's fibers extend from the periosteum and embed into the outer layers of bone.
    • This connection firmly anchors the periosteum to the underlying compact bone.
  • In Teeth:
    • They help attach the cementum of the tooth to the alveolar bone, forming part of the periodontal ligament complex.

Clinical Significance - Sunburst Appearance:

  • In aggressive bone tumors like osteosarcoma, there is periosteal reaction where Sharpey's fibers are laid down perpendicular to the cortex due to rapid tumor growth.
  • This radiates outward like sun rays on X-ray, giving the classical "sunburst" appearance.

questions.text: The total number of bones present in the appendicular and axial skeleton in adults is, respectively:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the adult, there are 126 bones in the appendicular skeleton and 80 bones in the axial skeleton.

choices.text: The sternoclavicular joint is a compound joint because it connects the clavicle and manubrium
The elbow joint is a complex joint because it permits both hinge and rotational movement
The wrist joint is a simple joint formed by articulation of the radius with the carpal bones
The temporomandibular joint is a complex joint due to the presence of an intra-articular disc

questions.text: Which of the following statements is anatomically correct regarding joint classification?
Which of the following is a modified long bone?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clavicle is a modified long bone, as it has a modified shaft and no medullary cavity.
